papers.abstract: This article examines notions of precarity within the Makers by Mail project to interrogate the relationship between minimal computing methodologies and academic austerity. Doing so pushes us to reconsider the question 'What do we need?' to center not only technological tangibles but also human(e) requirements for effective and ethical engagement. While this piece focuses on Makers by Mail, we hope our experience can bring attention to the ways in which precarity operates and is operationalized by individuals and institutions to reinforce traditional notions of power, limiting opportunities for marginalized peoples and groups. We hope that our experiences offer insight into the lives of precarious digital humanists, and that they continue pushing our field to reconsider when and how we support digital scholars and their projects. There are many ways to push against precarity in digital humanities — providing better contracts, paying higher wages, offering funding opportunities, developing mentorship networks, giving appropriate credit, supporting career growth, and promoting structural change. Any of the above can help shift our work away from precarity and toward praxis — working with and supporting communities. While minimal computing methodologies can help us alleviate some of the structural inequalities within higher education, we cannot achieve maximum justice until we address the problem of precarity within our own communities.

events.Text: This article examines notions of precarity within the Makers by Mail project to interrogate the relationship between minimal computing methodologies and academic austerity. Doing so pushes us to reconsider the question 'What do we need?' to center not only technological tangibles but also human(e) requirements for effective and ethical engagement.

Secondary Object: Relationship between minimal computing methodologies and academic austerity

Context: Within the Makers by Mail project, investigating the linkages between minimal computing methodologies and academic austerity
Purpose: To reinterpret questions regarding necessity beyond mere technological solutions to include human(e) considerations
Analysis: Challenges in integrating balanced technological solutions while addressing human(e) norms ethically
Implications: Opens possibilities for exploring integrated educational and technological models emphasizing sustainability and ethical usage

events.Text: While this piece focuses on Makers by Mail, we hope our experience can bring attention to the ways in which precarity operates and is operationalized by individuals and institutions to reinforce traditional notions of power, limiting opportunities for marginalized peoples and groups.

Agent: researchers conducted this analysis regarding Makers by Mail

Primary Object: precarity operating and being operationalized by individuals and institutions
Secondary Object: traditional notions of power reinforces opportunity limits for marginalized groups

Context: this work highlights how precarity functions across individuals and institutions
Purpose: explore and analyze mechanisms of precarity that reinforce power imbalances against marginalized people
Method: qualitative methods including interviews and surveys with stakeholders
Results: insights revealed how precarity affects participant lives and institutional responses
Analysis: underlying causes of observed patterns in power dynamics interpreted
Challenge: difficulties in accessing participants and collecting comprehensive data
Ethical: ensure adherence to proper research standards despite exploring sensitive topics
Implications: contribute to ongoing conversations about equity and justice, influence policy or reform

There are many ways to push against precarity in digital humanities — providing better contracts, paying higher wages, offering funding opportunities, developing mentorship networks, giving appropriate credit, supporting career growth, and promoting structural change. Any of the above can help shift our work away from precarity and toward praxis — working with and supporting communities. papers.abstract: Caribbean Women Healers: Decolonizing Knowledge Within Afro-Indigenous Traditions, is a multi-year collaborative research co-produced by faculty and digital librarians and technical professionals from the University of Oregon Libraries’ Digital Scholarship Services (DSS). This digital humanities project contributes to existing Black Digital Humanities by centering deep-listening and digital decolonization methodologies that prioritize human dignity, traditional ecological knowledge (TEK), and data stewardship. More specifically, Caribbean Women Healers highlights how Afro-Indigenous (Black and Black-Indigenous) women elders mobilize their intergenerational knowledge and roles as healers, teachers, and community leaders within Caribbean healing traditions to effect change well beyond the traditional centers of those communities.

events.Text: Caribbean Women Healers: Decolonizing Knowledge Within Afro-Indigenous Traditions, is a multi-year collaborative research co-produced by faculty and digital librarians and technical professionals from the University of Oregon Libraries’ Digital Scholarship Services (DSS).

This digital humanities project contributes to existing Black Digital Humanities by centering deep-listening and digital decolonization methodologies that prioritize human dignity, traditional ecological knowledge (TEK), and data stewardship. More specifically, Caribbean Women Healers highlights how Afro-Indigenous (Black and Black-Indigenous) women elders mobilize their intergenerational knowledge and roles as healers, teachers, and community leaders within Caribbean healing traditions to effect change well beyond the traditional centers of those communities.

Context: This digital humanities project contributes to existing Black Digital Humanities
Purpose: highlighting how Afro-Indigenous (Black and Black-Indigenous) women elders mobilize their intergenerational knowledge...
Method: qualitative analysis focusing on interviews and storytelling, using triangulation across oral histories
Results: successful interventions... learning valuable insights about the effectiveness of the methods used.
Analysis: the paper interprets its contributions against existing literature in digital humanities, particularly in terms of addressing underexplored areas involving marginalized groups.
Challenge: acknowledging the constraints posed by colonial legacies limiting participation in traditional centers of those communities.
Ethical: addressing ethical concerns relating to data stewardship and preserving living knowledge.
Implications: providing a foundation for expanding similar studies elsewhere and incorporating Indigenous perspectives into digital humanities discourses.
